choices.text: Increased refractive index of the nucleus of the lens
Decreased refractive index of the nucleus of the lens
Decreased refractive index of the cortex of the lens

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nuclear sclerosis increases the refractive index of the nucleus, leading to progressive myopia. (Rules out Option B)
  • Diabetic myopia occurs due to a decrease in the refractive index of the cortex of the lens.
  • Both mechanisms are associated with index myopia.

Key Takeaway:

Index Myopia is commonly seen in:

  • Nuclear sclerosis (increased lens nucleus refractive index).
  • Incipient cataract.
  • Diabetes (with changes in cortical refractive index).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bifocal lenses is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A:

Bifocal lenses have two distinct optical corrections-one for distance and another for near vision.

Option B:

These lenses are most commonly prescribed for presbyopes, who lose the ability to accommodate for near objects as they age.

Option C:

The design places the distance correction in the upper part of the lens and the near correction in the lower part, assisting with activities like reading or close work.

choices.text: PRK treats myopia by steepening the central corneal surface
LASEK involves the removal of the corneal epithelium using a mechanical microkeratome.
SMILE uses an excimer laser to cut a lenticule that is then removed mechanically.
LASIK requires a minimum of 250 μm residual stromal bed to avoid corneal ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about refractive laser procedures is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • LASIK requires at least 250 μm of residual stromal thickness to prevent iatrogenic corneal ectasia. This is a key safety consideration.
  • PRK treats myopia by flattening the central corneal surface, not steepening it. Flattening reduces corneal refractive power. (Ruled out Option A)
  • In LASEK, the epithelium is loosened using alcohol, not a mechanical microkeratome. (Ruled out Option B)
  • SMILE uses a femtosecond laser, not an excimer laser, to cut an intrastromal lenticule. (Ruled out Option C)

choices.text: Hruby lens and slit lamp (10× objective magnification)
Goldmann contact lens and slit lamp (10× objective magnification)

questions.text: Which of the following instruments produces an inverted and laterally reversed image of the retina during fundus examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The binocular indirect ophthalmoscope (IDO), used with a 20-diopter hand-held condensing lens, creates an aerial (real) image of the retina.
  • This image is:

Inverted (upside-down)

Laterally reversed (left/right flipped)

  • This occurs because the convex lens bends light rays to form a real image between the patient and the examiner.
  • The examiner views this image through the head-mounted device and mentally adjusts for the inversion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Direct ophthalmoscope (Option A): The direct ophthalmoscope produces an upright, non-inverted image of the retina because it is a direct optical system (virtual image viewed directly through the optics). However, it offers a narrow field of view (~10°) and no stereopsis.

Hruby lens and slit lamp (10× objective magnification) (Option C): The Hruby lens, used with a slit lamp, provides a virtual, erect, and laterally correct image of the posterior pole. It is primarily used to examine the optic disc and macula, but it does not invert the image.

Goldmann contact lens and slit lamp (10× objective magnification) (Option D): The Goldmann three-mirror contact lens produces a virtual, erect image for the central fundus and an indirect (reversed) image for the peripheral fundus. However, the central fundus (macula) is not inverted or reversed.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK587346/

questions.text: The diagram below shows Sturm's Conoid, with the retina placed at point F (the second focal line). Which type of astigmatism does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At point F, the horizontal meridian has focused exactly on the retina (emmetropic), but the vertical meridian is still diverging, acting myopic.

This describes Simple Myopic Astigmatism, where one meridian is myopic and the other is emmetropic.

In an astigmatic eye:

  • Light focuses differently in two directions:
    • In one direction (e.g., vertical), it focuses sooner.
    • In the other direction (e.g., horizontal), it focuses later.

This mismatch means light never comes to a single sharp point. Instead, it forms lines, ovals, or circles at different distances inside the eye.

Sturm's Conoid:

When parallel light rays enter an astigmatic eye:

Light is focused in two separate planes, one for each principal meridian. Between these two planes, the light rays form a three-dimensional hourglass-shaped structure called Sturm's conoid.


Position of the Retina Determines Type of Astigmatism:

Before first focus (A): Compound Hypermetropic Astigmatism

  • Both meridians focus behind the retina.

At first focus (B): Simple Hypermetropic Astigmatism

  • One meridian focused on the retina; the other was still hyperopic.

Between foci (C-D-E): Mixed Astigmatism

  • One meridian is myopic (focused in front of the retina), the other hyperopic.

At second focus (F): Simple Myopic Astigmatism

  • One meridian focused on the retina; the other myopic.

Beyond second focus (G): Compound Myopic Astigmatism

  • Both meridians focus in front of retina.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A young myopic patient presents with complaints of floaters and flashes of light. To thoroughly evaluate the retina, including the peripheral regions, which of the following is the most appropriate examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indirect ophthalmoscopy (IDO) is performed using a head-mounted binocular system and a 20-diopter hand-held condensing lens.

It allows:

Wide field of view (≈37°) for examining the entire retina, including the ora serrata and extreme periphery. Stereoscopic (3D) visualisation, helpful in identifying retinal detachments and elevated masses. Bright light for viewing even through cloudy ocular media. In this myopic patient, the symptoms of floaters and flashes raise concern for retinal tears or detachment, so IDO is the gold standard examination.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Direct Ophthalmoscopy (DDO) (Option B): DDO gives a narrow field of view (~10°) and cannot assess the retinal periphery where tears often occur. It lacks stereopsis, so 3D depth perception of retinal elevation is not possible.

Slit-lamp Biomicroscopy (Option C): Though useful for examining the posterior pole with special lenses, it is less effective for visualising the extreme periphery of the retina.

Cycloplegic Refraction (Option D): This is used to assess refractive errors (e.g., latent hyperopia) and has no role in retinal evaluation for floaters and flashes.

questions.text: At a distance of 6 meters, what is the angle subtended at the eye by the largest letter on a standard Snellen chart?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Snellen chart is designed so that:

  • Each letter on the 6/6 (20/20) line subtends 5 minutes of arc at the nodal point of the eye.
  • Each limb (stroke thickness) of these letters subtends 1 minute of arc.

The largest letter (the topmost "E") on a Snellen chart is 10 times bigger than the 6/6 letters. So:

  • At 6 meters, this letter subtends 5 minutes × 10 = 50 minutes of arc.

This can also be solve by: Angle subtended = (Denominator ÷ Numerator) × 5 minutes

For 6/60: (60 ÷ 6) × 5 = 50 minutes.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK558961/

questions.text: The following statements about the instrument shown (Pinhole aperture) are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pinhole aperture works by allowing only central rays to enter the eye, thus eliminating the effects of peripheral aberrations and refractive errors. (Supports Option A)

The aperture is typically 1 mm in diameter (Supports Option C)

It is useful for distinguishing refractive errors (up to ~3-4D) from pathological causes of reduced vision because it improves acuity in refractive errors but not in macular or posterior segment pathologies. PH acuity in macular disease or posterior lens opacities may be worse than with spectacle correction. (Rules out Option B)

The pinhole test is a quick clinical tool to assess whether reduced visual acuity is likely due to uncorrected refractive error. (Supports Option D)

choices.text: Fuchs spot at the macula following subretinal haemorrhage
Posterior staphyloma causing a dome-shaped macula
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment from asymptomatic atrophic holes
Early cortical cataract with "oil droplet" reflex

questions.text:
A 28-year-old East Asian woman presents with progressive visual decline and high myopia of -10 D. Fundus examination reveals the following findings:

Which of the following findings is LEAST likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fundus photo shows a Fuchs spot (a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula) - a hallmark complication of degenerative myopia following subretinal haemorrhage.

Degenerative myopia (pathological myopia) is a progressive condition characterised by excessive elongation of the eyeball (axial length >26 mm, refractive error >-6D). It is more common in East Asians and is associated with mechanical stretching of ocular tissues, leading to several characteristic fundus and ocular findings.

Key features of degenerative myopia include:

  • Fundus changes:
    • Fuchs spot: pigmented macular lesion following subretinal haemorrhage.
    • Posterior staphyloma: ectasia of the posterior sclera, sometimes leading to a dome-shaped macula.
    • Lacquer cracks: ruptures in RPE-Bruch's membrane complex.
    • Tessellated/tigroid fundus: prominent choroidal vessels due to RPE thinning.
    • Peripapillary atrophy and optic disc tilting.
  • Complications:
    • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (due to lattice degeneration, atrophic holes).
    • Choroidal neovascularisation (CNV).
    • Myopic macular retinoschisis.
    • Increased risk of glaucoma and early onset of nuclear/posterior subcapsular cataracts.

While posterior subcapsular or early onset nuclear sclerotic cataracts are associated with degenerative myopia, not cortical cataracts with an oil droplet reflex.

questions.text: Identify the chart depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Bailey-Lovie chart is used to measure logMAR visual acuity and is calibrated for testing at 6 meters. It has five letters per line with uniform spacing between letters and rows that is proportional to letter size. Unlike the Snellen chart, it provides equal difficulty across lines and assigns a 0.02 logMAR score per letter.

Explanation of Incorrect Option:

"Illiterate E" chart (Option B): Designed for young children or illiterate patients, where the patient identifies the direction of the letter "E". Letters are rotated in four directions (up, down, left, right).

Snellen visual acuity chart (Option C): Uses rows of letters of decreasing size for distance acuity testing. It does not have the proportional spacing or logMAR scoring used in the Bailey-Lovie chart.

Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart (Option D): Tests contrast sensitivity, not visual acuity. Letters are of equal size with decreasing contrast across rows, unlike Bailey-Lovie.

questions.text: You are assessing the visual acuity of a 3-year-old child. The test shown in the image involves seven familiar optotypes, presented for recognition at a test distance of 10 feet in children aged 3 years and 20 feet in children aged 5 years. Identify the test method shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Allen picture card test, commonly used for preschool vision screening, features seven black and white line drawings: a birthday cake, telephone, horseman, teddy bear, automobile, house, and tree. Each drawing is presented on a 10cm x 10cm white plastic card.

Explanation of Incorrect Option:

Lea Symbols Test (Option A): Uses four simple shapes (circle, square, apple, house) and is standardised for children unfamiliar with alphabets. Unlike Allen Cards, Lea Symbols are calibrated against the Landolt C and designed to blur equally.

Kay Picture Test (Option B): Uses child-friendly figures with matching cards for younger children or non-verbal children. Unlike Allen Cards, Kay Pictures are specifically designed for near and distance visual acuity assessment in preschoolers.

Sheridan-Gardiner HOTV Test (Option D): Relies on letter matching (H, O, T, V) and is useful for slightly older children (~4-5 years). Allen Cards differ because they use familiar objects instead of letters.

choices.text: Prismatic effects at the lens periphery causing the 'jack-in-the-box' phenomenon
Spherical aberrations leading to barrel distortion
Aspheric lens design causing oblique astigmatism

questions.text: A 60-year-old aphakic patient is using high-plus spectacle lenses after cataract extraction. He complains of seeing objects "jumping in and out of view" when he moves his eyes and also experiences distortion of straight lines in his peripheral vision. Which of the following optical phenomena best explains these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In high plus aphakic lenses, the strong convex curvature causes light rays entering at the lens periphery to bend excessively. This creates peripheral prismatic effects, which displace the image. As a result, objects at the edge of the field may abruptly appear or disappear when the patient moves their eyes - a phenomenon known as 'jack-in-the-box'

Explanation of Incorrect Option:

Spherical aberrations leading to barrel distortion (Option B): Spherical aberration happens when light rays entering the lens periphery focus at a different point compared to rays entering near the centre. In high plus lenses, this causes a pincushion effect, where straight lines near the edge of the visual field bow inward (like a pincushion), NOT barrel distortion. Barrel distortion, where lines bow outward, occurs in high minus lenses, not in aphakic (high plus) lenses.

Reduced vertex distance correcting magnification (Option C): Vertex distance errors are indeed an issue in aphakic lens corrections. However, reducing vertex distance does not eliminate magnification or correct peripheral aberrations like scotomas or pincushion distortion. The magnification in aphakic lenses remains approximately 25-30%, regardless of minor vertex adjustments.

Aspheric lens design causing oblique astigmatism (Option D): Aspheric lenses are specifically designed to minimise oblique astigmatism by gradually altering surface curvature from centre to edge. They allow for thinner, lighter, and flatter lenses with fewer off-axis aberrations. Aspheric lenses in aphakic correction are used to reduce prismatic effects and improve peripheral vision, not causing additional oblique astigmatism.

questions.text: A 12-year-old emmetropic child has a near point at 10 cm. What is the amplitude of accommodation in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amplitude of Accommodation is the maximum refractive power the eye can add through accommodation.
  • Formula: Amplitude (D) = 1/Near Point (in meters)
  • Here, near point = 10 cm = 0.1 m
  • Amplitude = 1/0.1 =10D

questions.text: A 7-year-old child undergoes retinoscopy under atropine cycloplegia. At a working distance of 1 meter, the examiner finds a +3.00 D reflex in both 90° and 180° meridians. What is the net glass prescription for this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Step 1: Retinoscopy gross finding

  • The gross retinoscopy result is +3.00 D at 1 meter.

Step 2: Apply working distance correction

  • The examiner's working distance is 1 meter → subtract 1.00 D from the gross result.
  • +3.00D - 1.00D = +2.00D

Step 3: Consider cycloplegia (Atropine)

  • Atropine tonus allowance = -1.00 D
  • +2.00D - 1.00D = +1.00D

Final Prescription: +1.00 D

questions.text: A prism produces displacement of the object seen through it towards the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A light ray passing through a prism obeys Snell's law and is bent toward the base of the prism.
  • However, the apparent image is displaced away from the base, i.e., towards the apex.
  • This happens because the brain assumes light travels in a straight line and projects the image in the direction of the prism's apex.

Reference: ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK580488/

questions.text: A 1 mm increase in the radius of curvature of the cornea leads to approximately how much hyperopia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Types of Hyperopia

Hyperopia occurs when light rays focus behind the retina in an unaccommodated eye.

Curvature Hyperopia: Due to flattening of the corneal or lens curvature. 1 mm increase in corneal radius of curvature = ~6D hyperopic shift.

Axial Hyperopia (Most common): Due to the shorter anterior-posterior length of the eyeball. 1 mm axial shortening = ~3D hyperopic shift.

Index Hyperopia: Caused by changes in the refractive index of the lens (seen in cortical cataracts, diabetes).

Positional Hyperopia: Due to malposition or absence of the crystalline lens (aphakia).

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560716/

choices.text: A toric surface with different curvatures in principal meridians
An irregular refracting surface with asymmetric curvatures

questions.text: Sturm's conoid represents the configuration of refracted rays when parallel light passes through:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sturm's Conoid:

  • It refers to the bundle of rays formed when light passes through a toric surface, i.e., one with different curvatures in perpendicular meridians (e.g., corneal surface in regular astigmatism).
  • These rays do not converge at a single point but form two focal lines separated by a distance known as the focal interval of Sturm.
  • Within this interval lies the circle of least diffusion, where the blur is minimised.

Explanation of Incorrect Option:

A concave spherical surface (Option A): In spherical surfaces (concave or convex), rays converge to a single focal point. Sturm's conoid is not formed.

A convex spherical surface (Option B): Spherical surfaces focus rays symmetrically in all meridians, unlike toric surfaces.

An irregular refracting surface with asymmetric curvatures (Option D): Irregular surfaces scatter rays asymmetrically and do not form Sturm's conoid.
